What is a System Environment?

If we think of our database instances as members in a herd of elephants, an environment is simply where they live. Some herds have small habitats and never leave a single area, while others travel far and wide. In a database context, this translates to some herds operating within a single data center, while others will span several depending on operational needs.

Servers then, are isolated habitats capable of hosting one or more herd members. These also exist exclusively within an environment, much like plots of land assigned to a territory. Yet multiple herds can reside within a single environment. This does not mean that each herd must exist on every server available, just that they can use any within the entire pool.

Example

We have ten production servers labeled A-J, and three herds: trading, tools and execution. We chose to create two environments to corral these herds:

  • Shared Prod: Servers A-H, hosting trading or tools as needed.
  • Big Prod: Servers I and J, larger servers set aside for things like the execution herd.
